docs.snippet: Santos beat Penarol, 2-1, to win the Copa Libertadores for the first time since Pele was in the team, but its celebration was marred by a postgame brawl between the teams.
docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil’s Santos beat Peñarol of Uruguay, 2-1, on Wednesday night in Sao Paulo to win the Copa Libertadores for the first time since Pelé was in the team, but its celebration was marred by a postgame brawl between the teams.
docs.abstract: Santos beat Penarol, 2-1, to win the Copa Libertadores for the first time since Pele was in the team, but its celebration was marred by a postgame brawl between the teams.

docs.snippet: Fortunato’s jewelry collection for resort was inspired by her travel to Uruguay, Guatemala and Texas.
docs.lead_paragraph: “I am a magpie collecting things everywhere I go,” says Lizzie Fortunato, the designer behind her namesake Lizzie Fortunato Jewels line. Her finds have included antique whalebone poker chips in Montevideo, Uruguay, textiles from a Guatemalan village and vintage arrows at a flea market in rural Texas. This inspiration from travel is delightfully apparent in her resort collection, “Paradise Is an Island.” The assortment is a tropical concoction of polychromatic glass beads, winsome brass arrowheads and carnelian tusks, all strung together on gold chains and rope — the perfect colorful addition to an urbanite’s summer wardrobe. Despite each piece having names of exotic vacation hot spots, like “Easter Island Necklace,” the root of the label could not be more down-to-earth. For Fortunato, jewelry has always been a natural outlet. “By the time I was in college, I was fashioning statement necklaces out of industrial bolts and chains, glass beads that a friend toted back from South Africa and family heirloom pieces — literally anything I could get my hands on,” she explains. The results are a fusion of high and low, with thoughtful handiwork and smart combinations of pearls, colorful rope and shapely gold.
docs.abstract: Fortunato’s jewelry collection for resort was inspired by her travel to Uruguay, Guatemala and Texas.

headline.main: Don’t Forget Resort Jewels | Lizzie Fortunato

docs.snippet: Mark J. Gerard, a veterinarian who cared for champion racehorses like Kelso and Secretariat but who perpetrated one of the most notorious racetrack frauds of the postwar era, died June 21 in Miami. He was 76.     The cause was complications of a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mark J. Gerard, a veterinarian who cared for champion racehorses like Kelso and Secretariat but who perpetrated one of the most notorious racetrack frauds of the postwar era, died June 21 in Miami. He was 76. The cause was complications of a stroke, his sister, Joyce Aimee Titchnell, said.
docs.abstract: Mark J Gerard, veterinarian who cared for champion race horses and was involved in a notorious 1970s horse identity switch, dies at age 76. Photo (M)

headline.main: Mark J. Gerard, a Racing Veterinarian Involved in a Horse Switch, Dies at 76

docs.snippet: Esteban Paredes and Arturo Vidal scored second-half goals as Chile rallied to beat Mexico, 2-1, on Monday in a Group C match in the Copa América in San Juan, Argentina. Uruguay scored in first-half stoppage time and tied Peru, 1-1.     Fielding a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Esteban Paredes and Arturo Vidal scored second-half goals as Chile rallied to beat Mexico, 2-1, on Monday in a Group C match in the Copa América in San Juan, Argentina. Uruguay scored in first-half stoppage time and tied Peru, 1-1. Fielding a youth team, Mexico took a lead in the 41st minute on Nestor Araujo's header after Chile had dominated possession. Eight Mexican players had been suspended after women were found in their hotel rooms during training.
docs.abstract: Chile defeats Mexico, 2-1, in Copa America soccer match; other soccer results noted. (M)

headline.main: Chile Rallies to Beat Mexico in Copa América
